Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2008 01:57PM bapnkat wrote: Michelle, Thanks so much!  I am stage 3 and almost 38.  I had 14 lymph nodes which were cancerous.  I hope I will be here five years from now, too. Kate
Posts.Title: 5 years this week. Carmelle sue_m

Posts.Content: bapnkat wrote: My surgery is scheduled for Wednesday at noon.  I have to say what has me the most scared is the injections of radiation for the nodes.  I've heard such awful things about it.  The doctor even said it would be very painful.  Why can't they do this after you are asleep?  Anyway, I'll be having both breasts removed.  I had to talk them into it, but they finally agreed since I was so insistent.  Kate Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Surgery bapnkat melody

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2007 05:58AM bapnkat wrote: i did have a biopsy.  They removed two  lumps and they had used wires and all that.  It was not painful at all.  Actually I never really felt any of those injections or anything, but I had heard that the radioactive dye used before your mammogram was VERY painful.  Even the doctor said it would probably hurt alot.  That was what had me the most worried.  Kate
Posts.Title: Surgery bapnkat melody

Posts.Content: bapnkat wrote: Has anyone who has a lot of lymph nodes infected ever find that the cancer has NOT spread?  I heard that if you have multiple lymph nodes infected, as I do (13) that you most definately have it somewhere.  This is a bit worrisome.  Thanks Kate Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: possible? bapnkat bapnkat

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 03:45PM bapnkat wrote: The appointment with the oncologist went well.  I did find out that my two lumps that were removed were about 2 1/2 centimeters.  Also, he said there is a slight chance it is in the nodes because of something on the mammogram.  He drew a diagram and said something about my estrogen levels being high and that it was a good sign, but I don't know exactly what he was talking about.  He said something about receptors and such.  Anyway, he said we need to do the masectomy soon and then I would do chemo for 4 or 5 months and they want me to take some sort of pill.  I can't remember the name of it except that it begins with T.  I am supposed to see the surgeon tomorrow and see the oncologist in about a week for blood test and discussion.   Kate
Posts.Title: A question about symptoms bapnkat chemo072

Posts.Content: bapnkat wrote: I just got back from vacation yesterday and will be seeing an oncologist today.  I have only had a biopsy so I have no idea as of yet what stage I am at, only that they removed two lumps which were cancerous during the biopsy and that my surgeon said there were no lumps attached to the chest wall that he could see.  I have searched for symptoms of cancer other than lumps but have found none.  Has anyone experienced any symptoms before diagnosis besides finding a lump?  I had off and on nausea for about six months or so that would last just a few minutes, and I wondered if it was because of this or maybe it's something else.  Has anyone ever had any symptoms? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A question about symptoms bapnkat chemo072

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 12:46PM bapnkat wrote: Thank you all for the encouragement.  Believe me, I feel much better now.  I've had three chemos and have five to go.  So far everything is going good.  God's bigger than cancer, anyway. Kate
Posts.Title: possible? bapnkat bapnkat

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2008 09:25PM bapnkat wrote: Hi all.  I just asked my doc about this the other day and he told me studies have proven diet doesn't affect breast cancer.   HMMM...I'll have to look in to this more. Kate

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2007 10:24PM bapnkat wrote: My surgeon took out my drains the day after surgery.  I had four.  I have only had to have the side where lymph nodes were removed aspirated, so I guess I'm doing ok.  Surgery was two weeks and one day ago today.  Kate
